I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Assam  Urban  Infrastructure  Investment 
Program. 
 
2. 
The  proposed  MFF  will  finance  a  portion  of  the  urban  infrastructure  initiatives  of  the 
Government  of  Assam  for  the  cities  of  Guwahati  and  Dibrugarh. 1 It  will  improve  the  urban 
services in these cities by improving water supply, sanitation, solid waste management (SWM), 
drainage infrastructure, and urban transport to the standards set by the State.2
  
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Assam  is the gateway for  developing  India’s  northeast  because  of  its  strategic  position

and relatively large population of 31.17 million.3
 An examination of urban service delivery in the 
13  largest  towns  of  Assam found most  performance  indicators  below  the  national  average,  as

incremental  wastewater  that  will  be  generated  by  the  water  supply  subprojects.  Rapid

prone to severe local flooding during the rainy season.

7. 
Strategic  context  for  ADB  and  urban  service  delivery.  The  country  partnership 
strategy 13 and  ADB’s  assistance  program  for  2007–2012  support  the  Government  of  India’s 
efforts  to  address  binding  constraints  on  the  plan  through  four  strategic  pillars.14 The  country 
partnership  strategy  stresses  continuing  ADB’s  assistance  to  infrastructure  development, 
including  urban  infrastructure.  The  country  operations  business  plan  for  India,  2011–2013 15
 
allocates an MFF of up to $200 million for the Assam Urban Infrastructure Investment Program 
for processing in 2011. 
 
8. 
India  and  urban  service  delivery.  India’s  plan  has  set  out  27  national  targets,  both 
economic  and  social,  including  (i)  clean  drinking  water  available  to  all  by  2009,  ensuring  that 
there is no slippage by the end of the plan, and (ii) treating all urban wastewater by 2011–2012 
to reduce river pollution. The plan calls for public investment to meet infrastructure requirements 
where private participation is less likely. 
 
Policy  framework  and  ongoing  initiatives.  The  Government  of  India  has  been  the 
9. 
most prominent financier in Assam through various national schemes. The centrally sponsored 
JNNURM,  the  Urban  Infrastructure  Development  Scheme  for  Small  and  Medium  Towns,  and 
other  national  and  state  budgetary  allocations  are  available  but  inadequate  to  meet  the 
complete  investment  requirement.  The  government  has  undertaken  several  initiatives  for 
economic  development  in  the  northeast  with  ADB  assistance.  During  the  2010  country 
programming mission, Assam was identified as the recipient of the proposed ADB assistance. 
 
10. 
Investment program for urban infrastructure in Guwahati and Dibrugarh, including 
external  assistance. Major investments in urban infrastructure were identified in the 2006 city 
development plan, aiming to attract funding from the JNNURM. The plan envisions investments 
in  Guwahati  and  Dibrugarh  of  $860.49  million,  toward  which  financing  secured  from  the 
JNNURM is $143.58 million and JICA $318.00 million, leaving a funding gap of $398.91 million. 
ADB  financing  of  $200.00  million  was  requested.  The  Government  of  Assam  is  seeking  an 
additional  $120.00 million from  JICA for  wastewater treatment  and  networks  in Guwahati. The 
balance  of  $78.91  million  will  be  financed  by  the  Government  of  Assam.  The  urban  services 
investment  program  in  Guwahati  of  $575.36  million,  supported  by  ADB,  JICA,  and  JNNURM, 
covers  44%  of  the  total  investment  requirement  of  $1.30  billion  for  the  13  largest  cities  in 
Assam.  Similarly,  the  investment  program  for  urban  transport  in  Guwahati  of  $205.12  million 
covers 20% of the total urban transport investment requirement of $1.00 billion for the 13 largest 
cities. 
 
11. 
The  MFF  modality  was  selected  to  allow  phased  implementation  and  funding  of 
individual projects when they are ready, subject to eligibility and readiness of subprojects which 
are  16 included  in  the  investment  program.17 The  requirements  for  an  MFF  are  in  place.  The 
Government of Assam has prepared a sector strategy supported by an investment plan over the 
next ten years.18

 Impact and Outcome 

Policy dialogue. Policy dialogue with the Government of Assam will develop a strategic 
12. 
and  integrated  approach  to  sustainably  improving  the  urban  environment  and  quality  of  life. 
First, meters installed for all consumers in the service areas will support the transition from the 
current  flat  rates  to  volumetric  rates  for  water  supply,  enhancing  cost  recovery,  demand 
management, and water conservation.19 Second, institutional reforms will improve the efficiency 
and  strengthen  the  capacity  of the  Guwahati  Metropolitan Water  Supply  and  Sewerage  Board 
(GMWSSB),  which  will  be  an  autonomous  entity  responsible  for  managing  and  operating  all 
water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities  in  Guwahati,  including  the  collection  of  tariffs,  with  effect 
from  2015.20 Third,  institutional  reform  and  organizational  development  in  urban  transport  will 
bring  into  being  an  authority  to  plan,  manage,  and  coordinate  all  transportation  in  the  city. 
Further, policy and institutional reforms under the JNNURM in Guwahati complements the policy 
dialogue under the investment program (footnote 8). Key lessons from past ADB water supply 
projects21
 have been considered in the design of the investment program, including the need to 
increase water use efficiency and focus on cost recovery and institutional matters.  Further, the 
GDD  will  prepare  a  detailed  road  map  for  revising  tariffs,  setting  out  milestones  toward 
introducing  revised  water  tariffs  to  meet  full  O&M  costs,  and  establishing  sewerage  fees  and 
solid waste management user charges in Guwahati and Dibrugarh by 2018. 
 
B. 
 
The  impact  of  the  investment  program  will  be  an  improved  access  to  water  supply, 
13. 
sanitation, and urban infrastructure facilities by the urban population in Guwahati and Dibrugarh. 
The  expected  outcome  will  be  improved  and  sustainable  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  urban 
transport  system  in  Guwahati  and  Dibrugarh.  The  investment  program  will  help  India  achieve 
the Millennium Development Goals on environment sustainability and increased access to safe 
drinking water and basic sanitation. An integrated and holistic approach is being designed under 
which  six  outputs  will  be  delivered. The  two tranches  under the  MFF  will  be  implemented  in  6 
years from 2012 to 2017.22
 
 
C. 
 
14. 
Output  1:  Improved  water  supply  infrastructure  in  Guwahati.  Investments  will 
provide high-quality, 24-hour-a-day water supply to 350,000 residents in the southeastern zone 
of Guwahati by 2018.23
 This includes constructing a water intake and water diversion structures, 
water  treatment  facility,  water  transmission  system  and  service  reservoirs,  laying  all-new 
distribution pipes, and limiting nonrevenue water to less than 15%, which is below the Ministry 
of Urban Development benchmark of 20%. 
 
15. 
Output  2:  Improved  sewerage  infrastructure  in  Guwahati. Investments will address 
100% of the incremental wastewater generated by the ADB-funded water supply subproject. It

 The  main  outputs  are  (i)  blueprint 
organizational  structure for GMWSSB  as  a  ring-fenced  and  sustainable  autonomous  entity;  (ii)

toolkit  to  be  used  to  implement  public–private  partnership  projects  in  urban  services;  and  (iv) 
management information system for use by ULB managers and state government officials.

A. 
 
All  physical  components  will  be  designed  to  withstand  earthquakes.  Mitigation  will  be 
26. 
designed  into  land  development,  transmission  and  distribution  pipelines,  building  foundations 
and  structures,  road  pavements,  and  other  urban  infrastructure.  Geological  and  geotechnical 
analysis  during  detailed  design  will  ensure  that  pipelines  and  road  alignments  follow  feasible 
routes. Energy-efficient technical options to reduce operating costs will be pursued. Most water-
supply and wastewater-treatment systems will be gravity fed, to minimize O&M costs. The storm 
water  drainage  subproject  in  Dibrugarh  will  increase  channel  flow  capacity  and  reduce  flood 
risk.  Further,  the  procurement  of  new  equipment  and  construction  of  new  sanitary  landfill  will 
improve  solid  waste  management, making  Dibrugarh  cleaner  and  putting  it  in  compliance  with 
the  Municipal  Solid  Waste  (Management  &  Handling)  Rules,  2000.  Rigorous  and  detailed 
analysis  of  technical  options  and  design  optimization  have  avoided  significant  resettlement 
impacts from the Guwahati water treatment plant and the SWM landfill in Dibrugarh.

and  least-cost  designs,  as  well  as  ensure  economic  internal  rates  of  return  higher  than  the 
economic opportunity cost of capital, as specified in the subproject selection criteria of the FFA. 
Under  project  1,  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is  16%  for  the  Guwahati  water  supply 
subproject,  19.7%  for  the  Dibrugarh  drainage  improvement  subproject,  and  14.4%  for  the 
Dibrugarh solid waste management subproject. Financial internal rates of return and net present 
value  have  been  computed  for  the  revenue-generating  water  supply  and  solid  waste 
management subproject at May 2011 prices. The financial internal rate of return is 4.7% for the 
Guwahati  water  supply  subproject  and  7.4%  for  the  Dibrugarh  solid  waste  management 
subproject, both above the weighted average cost of capital of 3.21%.

The  investment  program  supports  Millennium  Development  Goal  7,  on  environmental 
sustainability.  Pro-poor  interventions  in  project  1  include  (i)  a  baseline  survey  to  identify  poor 
and vulnerable households for service delivery, (ii) a community awareness program to educate 
and  inform  the  poor  of  investment  program  benefits,  (iii)  a  behavioral  change  program  to 
improve personal sanitation and hygiene, and (iv) a community-based primary waste collection 
system  in  Dibrugarh.  As  tranche  1  is  classified  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming,  a  gender 
action plan and consultation and participation strategy were prepared to ensure widespread and 
meaningful  participation  with  an  emphasis  on  the  poor  and  women.31
 The  gender  action  plan 
and consultation and participation strategy will be implemented with the assistance of an NGO 
and quarterly monitoring and reporting of progress.

31. 
Environmental  safeguards.  Tranche  1  is  classified  category  B  for  environment. 
Tranche  2  is  expected  to  be  classified  category  B  (to  be  confirmed  during  implementation). 
Three  initial  environmental  examinations  were  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  government  laws.  Environmental  benefits  include  (i)  more  and 
better  drinking  water  and reduced  waterborne  disease  in Guwahati, (ii)  reduced  contamination 
of soil and waterways and emissions of harmful gases from improved solid waste management 
in  Dibrugargh,  and  (iii)  reduced  waterborne  disease  and  flooding  from  improved  drainage  in 
Dibrugargh. Consultant support will ensure that the PMU and the PIUs have adequate capacity 
to  manage  environmental  impacts.  The  subprojects  are  likely  to  cause  minor-to-moderate 
environmental  disruption  during  construction.  The  GDD  will  be 
for 
implementing the mitigating measures specified in the initial environmental examinations, which, 
along  with  environmental  management  plans,  will  be  updated  during  detailed  design  and 
incorporated  into  bidding  and  contract  documents.  Environmental  reporting  to  ADB  will  be 
semiannual.  An  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  was  prepared  to  guide  the 
preparation of subprojects in tranche 2.32
 
 
32. 
Social  safeguards. Tranche 1 is classified category B for involuntary resettlement and 
category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  Tranche  2  is  potentially  category  A  for  involuntary 
resettlement  and  indicatively  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples  (to  be  confirmed  during 
implementation).  For  tranche  1  subprojects,  three  draft  resettlement  plans  were  prepared  in 
consultation  with  affected  people,  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement, 
and  disclosed.  Tranche  1  requires  minor  land  acquisition  with  no  significant  resettlement 
impacts anticipated. The resettlement plans will be implemented by the PIUs and monitored by 
the PMU. Adequate international and national consultancy inputs will be provided by the design 
and supervision consultant, project management consultant, and NGO and through the loan and 
TA  to  support  the  resettlement  plan,  implementation,  and  monitoring.  Capacity  will  be  built  for 
managing  the  resettlement  impacts  and  social  risks  of  the  investment  program,  including 
potential impacts arising from the BRT component in tranche 2. As these subprojects are urban, 
no impact on indigenous people is expected. A resettlement framework and indigenous peoples 
planning framework were prepared to guide the preparation of subprojects in tranche 2.33
